thread.title: Five Arsenal players who deserve to start in the FA Cup clash with Preston North End
thread.title_full: Five Arsenal players who deserve to start in the FA Cup clash with Preston North End

author: Hamish Mackay
title: Five Arsenal players who deserve to start in the FA Cup clash with Preston North End

organizations.name: preston north end sport five arsenal

text:
Sport Five Arsenal players who deserve to start in the FA Cup clash with Preston North End The only two English sides to complete a league season without losing a game will go head-to-head in the Sunday's late fixture Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Arsene Wenger speaks ahead of Preston trip Share this video Get Arsenal FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Arsenal's FA Cup campaign gets underway on Saturday with a trip to face Preston North End at Deepdale. 
The only two English sides to complete a league season without losing a game will go head-to-head in the day's late fixture. 
While Simon Grayson looks set to field his strongest side, Arsene Wenger is likely to select some of his fringe players. 
The FA Cup is the only major competition Arsenal have won in the last decade, and it could prove pivotal in a season in which the club try to convince their star players they are capable of winning trophies. 
Mesut Ozil and Alex Sanchez are both negotiating new deals, and both will want assurances over the club's competitiveness as well as pay rises. 
At this stage in the tournament, though, Arsenal should feel confident of advancing to the next round regardless of the starting XI, and fixtures like this provide brilliant opportunities for squad players to get valuable playing time. 
With that in mind, MirrorFootball has selected five players Arsene Wenger must start on Saturday. Jeff Reine-Adelaide Jeff Reine-Adelaide takes on Theo Epailly of PSG in the UEFA Youth Champions League (Photo: David Price) 
With Arsenal out of the EFL Cup, Reine-Adelaide's first team prospects look limited this season. The Frenchman has been named on the bench in each of Arsenal's last three Premier League games but is yet to make an appearance in the competition. 
Wenger is not interested in sending Reine-Adelaide on loan but, at 18, the midfielder is at an important stage of his development and desperately in need of senior experience. 
Arsenal paid more than £2million for him 18 months ago and he is arguably their most promising teenager, but he won't realise that potential without first team appearances. 
While yet to really impress in any of his five senior games for Arsenal, Reine-Adelaide has not looked out of his depth and is at an age where few good performances could increase his development exponentially. Rob Holding Rob Holding holds off pressure from Sam McQueen during the EFL Cup quarter-final (Photo: Mike Hewitt) 
Holding's start to life at Arsenal bore a remarkable resemblance to that of Calum Chambers, but fans will be hoping his development does not follow the same tragectory. 
After a strong start, Chambers had a few tough games and lost his confidence. What followed was a period of stagnation and a lack of game time. It was hoped Chambers would be competing for a starting spot by now, instead he finds himself on loan at Middlesbrough. 
This time last year, Holding was playing for Bolton against Eastleigh. Now he's at Arsenal and has already made seven appearances this season. But with no chance of him forcing himself into Wenger's first XI and no loan in sight, the FA Cup appears to be his sole platform for appearances. 
He has experience facing Championship clubs so Deepdale will hold no fear for him and he has already proven his quality this season. He must start. Lucas Perez Lucas Perez scores a stunning goal against Bournemouth (Photo: AFP/Getty) 
Lucas is a doubt for the game due to an ankle problem but if he can start, he must. 
The 28-year-old has six goals in his 12 appearances this season, including a volley Robin van Persie would have been proud of in Arsenal's 3-3 draw with Bournemouth. 
Lucas is fresh, hungry and in form. Whether he starts up front or on the wing may depend upon Danny Welbeck's fitness. Either way, he deserves a place in the lineup. Read More Ainsley Maitland-Niles Arsene Wenger talks with Ainsley Maitland-Niles during a training session (Photo: Stuart MacFarlane) 
Last season's loan spell at Ipswich began well, with Maitland-Niles securing a starting spot under Mick McCarthy. By spring, though, the teenager's attitude had left him on the fringes of the squad and Wenger has opted to keep him in north London for 2016/17. 
He featured in all three EFL Cup games, as well as the 4-1 win away to Sunderland in the league. Now, though, he finds his prospects limited so will be hoping for a start in the FA Cup. 
Wenger's decision to try Maitland-Niles — normally a winger — at full-back this season is an interesting development and his versatility certainly increases the chances of him playing. 
Mathieu Debuchy and Carl Jenkinson would both normally be ahead of the 19-year-old in the right-back pecking order, but Wenger admitted this week he was happy for both to leave. If Maitland-Niles has a future at Arsenal and the other two do not, it would seem a wasted opportunity if the teenager did not start against Preston. Chuba Akpom Chuba Akpom celebrates after winning a penalty against Nottingham Forest (Photo: Getty) 
Akpom's struggles for both form and fitness over the past 18 months have been accentuated by the rise of Alex Iwobi, who came through the ranks with the striker. 
While Iwobi is competing for places every week in the Premier League, Akpom — originally thought to be the more promising of the duo — struggled to play regularly at Hull last season and has spent most of the current campaign out injured. 
There is still time for Akpom, whose youth goals-coring record is outstanding, to make it Arsenal. At 21, though, that time is running out. Like us on Facebook
